Class Category

java.lang.Object
regexodus.Category
All Implemented Interfaces:
CharPredicate
public class Category extends Object implements CharPredicate
Unicode categories constructed from tightly compressed string and array literals instead of large resources. Credit for the technique and much of the code goes to gagern, from this Gist. Also, the heavy amount of work that went into the Unicode DB for Node.js (which the pre-processing stage for this depends on) must be commended; that project is node-unicode-data.

    C
    All control, format, surrogate, private use, and unassigned characters; Unicode category C.

    static final Category
    Format
    All format characters; Unicode category Cf.
    static final Category
    G
    Whitespace characters, both horizontal and vertical; not an actual Unicode category but acts like the combination of Horizontal (Zh in regexes) and Vertical (Zv in regexes) in that it includes both the obscure Unicode characters that are in the Unicode Z category but also the practical characters such as carriage return, newline, and horizontal tab that are not classified as whitespace by Unicode but are by everyone else.
    static final Category
    Gh
    Horizontal whitespace characters; not an actual Unicode category but probably more useful because it contains the horizontal tab character while Unicode's Z category does not.
    static final Category
    Gv
    Vertical whitespace characters; not an actual Unicode category but probably more useful because it contains the newline and carriage return characters while Unicode's Z category does not.
    static final Category
    Horizontal
    Horizontal whitespace characters; not an actual Unicode category but probably more useful because it contains the horizontal tab character while Unicode's Z category does not.
    static final Category
    Identifier
    All valid characters that can be used in a Java identifier.
    static final Category
    IdentifierPart
    All valid characters that can be used as the second or later character in a Java identifier.
    static final Category
    IdentifierStart
    All valid characters that can be used as the first character in a Java identifier (more than you might think).
    static final Category
    InitialPunctuation
    All initial/opening "quote-like" punctuation; Unicode category Pi.
    static final Category

    All valid characters that can be used in a Java identifier.
    static final Category

    static final Category

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type
    Method
    Description
    static char
    caseDown(char c)
    Returns the given char c's lower-case representation, if it has one, otherwise returns it verbatim.
    static char
    caseFold(char c)
    Returns the given char c's lower-case representation, if it has one, otherwise returns it verbatim.
    static char
    caseUp(char c)
    The counterpart to caseDown(char) that returns the given char c's upper-case representation, if it has one, otherwise it returns it verbatim.
    boolean
    contains(char checking)
    Returns true if the input is contained in this Category, otherwise returns false.
    char[]
    contents()
    Gets all chars in this Category as a char array.
    CharBitSet
    decompress()
    When a Category's compression slows down its repeated usage, you can get an uncompressed data structure using this method.
    boolean
    equals(Object o)
     
    int
    hashCode()
     
    static boolean
    isCurrency(char c)
    Returns true if c is a Unicode currency symbol, in category Sc, or false otherwise.
    static boolean
    isDigit(char c)
    Returns true if c is a Unicode decimal digit, in category Nd, or false otherwise.
    static boolean
    isISOControl(char c)
    Returns true if c is an ISO control character, in the ranges 0x00 to 0x1F or 0x7F to 0x9F, or false otherwise.
    static boolean
    isJavaIdentifierPart(char c)
    Returns true if c is allowed as a later part of a Java identifier, meaning a letter, a number, a currency symbol, a connecting punctuation character such as the underscore, or a "letter number", or false otherwise.
    static boolean
    isJavaIdentifierStart(char c)
    Returns true if c is allowed as the start of a Java identifier, meaning a letter, a currency symbol, a connecting punctuation character such as the underscore, or a "letter number", or false otherwise.
    static boolean
    isLetter(char c)
    Returns true if c is a Unicode letter, in category L, or false otherwise.
    static boolean
    isLowerCase(char c)
    Returns true if c is a Unicode lower-case letter, in category Ll, or false otherwise.
    static boolean
    isMath(char c)
    Returns true if c is a Unicode math symbol, in category Sm, or false otherwise.
    static boolean
    isUpperCase(char c)
    Returns true if c is a Unicode upper-case letter, in category Lu, or false otherwise.
    static boolean
    isWhitespace(char c)
    Returns true if c is a whitespace character, including space, tab, newline, carriage return, and more Unicode space characters, or false otherwise.
    static boolean
    isWord(char c)
    Returns true if c is a "word-like" character, meaning a letter, a number, or the underscore, or false otherwise.
    static char
    matchBracket(char c)
    Finds the matching closing or opening bracket when given an opening or closing bracket as the char c.
    static boolean
    reverseBracketEqual(CharSequence left, CharSequence right)
    Returns true if left and right are reverses of each other with the same length, and any brackets also reversed via matchBracket(char).
    static boolean
    reverseEqual(CharSequence left, CharSequence right)
    Returns true if left and right are reverses of each other with the same length.
    static String
    reverseWithBrackets(CharSequence s)
    Returns a String that is the reverse of s, with any brackets also reversed via matchBracket(char).
    boolean
    test(char value)
    Returns true if the input is contained in this Category, otherwise returns false.
    String
    toString()

    • Z

      public static final Category Z
      Some whitespace characters; Unicode category Z. This has some notable missing characters, like newline, tab (both horizontal and vertical), and carriage return; you may want Horizontal and/or Vertical, which don't line up to Unicode categories but do match the correct sets of horizontal and vertical whitespace. There is also the option of Space as the fusion of both Horizontal and Vertical.

    • Separator

      public static final Category Separator
      Some whitespace characters; Unicode category Z. This has some notable missing characters, like newline, tab (both horizontal and vertical), and carriage return; you may want Horizontal and/or Vertical, which don't line up to Unicode categories but do match the correct sets of horizontal and vertical whitespace. There is also the option of Space as the fusion of both Horizontal and Vertical.

      Some space separator characters; Unicode category Zs.

    • Word

      public static final Category Word
      All "programming word" characters, an odd group that includes all letters, all numbers, and the underscore '_'. You may want Identifier, IdentifierPart, and/or IdentifierStart for Java identifier characters, which are a larger group and allow matching the initial character differently from the rest.
      Accessible in regexes via "\w" when Unicode mode hasn't been explicitly disabled.

    • J

      public static final Category J
      All valid characters that can be used in a Java identifier.
      Accessible in regexes via "\pJ" or "\p{J}" (J for Java).

    • Identifier

      public static final Category Identifier
      All valid characters that can be used in a Java identifier.
      Accessible in regexes via "\pJ" or "\p{J}" (J for Java).

    • Js

      public static final Category Js
      All valid characters that can be used as the first character in a Java identifier (more than you might think).
      Accessible in regexes via "\p{Js}".

    • IdentifierStart

      public static final Category IdentifierStart
      All valid characters that can be used as the first character in a Java identifier (more than you might think).
      Accessible in regexes via "\p{Js}".

    • Jp

      public static final Category Jp
      All valid characters that can be used as the second or later character in a Java identifier. This is identical to J.
      Accessible in regexes via "\p{Jp}".

    • IdentifierPart

      public static final Category IdentifierPart
      All valid characters that can be used as the second or later character in a Java identifier. This is identical to Identifier.
      Accessible in regexes via "\p{Jp}".

    • Gh

      public static final Category Gh
      Horizontal whitespace characters; not an actual Unicode category but probably more useful because it contains the horizontal tab character while Unicode's Z category does not.
      Accessible in regexes via "\p{Zh}" or "\p{Gh}" .

    • Horizontal

      public static final Category Horizontal
      Horizontal whitespace characters; not an actual Unicode category but probably more useful because it contains the horizontal tab character while Unicode's Z category does not.
      Accessible in regexes via "\p{Zh}" or "\p{Gh}" .

    • Gv

      public static final Category Gv
      Vertical whitespace characters; not an actual Unicode category but probably more useful because it contains the newline and carriage return characters while Unicode's Z category does not.
      Accessible in regexes via "\p{Zv}" or "\p{Gv}" .

    • Vertical

      public static final Category Vertical
      Vertical whitespace characters; not an actual Unicode category but probably more useful because it contains the newline and carriage return characters while Unicode's Z category does not.
      Accessible in regexes via "\p{Zv}" or "\p{Gv}" .

    • G

      public static final Category G
      Whitespace characters, both horizontal and vertical; not an actual Unicode category but acts like the combination of Horizontal (Zh in regexes) and Vertical (Zv in regexes) in that it includes both the obscure Unicode characters that are in the Unicode Z category but also the practical characters such as carriage return, newline, and horizontal tab that are not classified as whitespace by Unicode but are by everyone else. This is likely different from the regex \s because it includes some control characters used as whitespace (such as the carriage return).
      Accessible in regexes via "\pG" or "\p{G}" (G for Gap).

    • Space

      public static final Category Space
      Whitespace characters, both horizontal and vertical; not an actual Unicode category but acts like the combination of Horizontal (Zh in regexes) and Vertical (Zv in regexes) in that it includes both the obscure Unicode characters that are in the Unicode Z category but also the practical characters such as carriage return, newline, and horizontal tab that are not classified as whitespace by Unicode but are by everyone else. This is likely different from the regex \s because it includes some control characters used as whitespace (such as the carriage return).
      Accessible in regexes via "\pG" or "\p{G}" (G for Gap).

    • OPENING_BRACKETS

      public static final String OPENING_BRACKETS
      An immutable String showing all chars, in a specific order, that are considered "opening" brackets, braces, parentheses, quotation marks, and so on. This matches the exact size and order used by CLOSING_BRACKETS, and you can use the same index in the two Strings to get an opening and closing pair.

    • CLOSING_BRACKETS

      public static final String CLOSING_BRACKETS
      An immutable String showing all chars, in a specific order, that are considered "closing" brackets, braces, parentheses, quotation marks, and so on. This matches the exact size and order used by OPENING_BRACKETS, and you can use the same index in the two Strings to get an opening and closing pair.

    • contents

      public char[] contents()

    • contains

      public boolean contains(char checking)
      Returns true if the input is contained in this Category, otherwise returns false.
      This method runs in linear time proportional to the compressed size of the Category. If it isn't fast enough, you can use decompress() and run CharBitSet.contains(char) instead.
      Parameters:
      checking - the input argument
      Returns:
      true if the input is contained in this Category, otherwise false

    • caseFold

      public static char caseFold(char c)
      Returns the given char c's lower-case representation, if it has one, otherwise returns it verbatim. This is currently the same as caseDown(char), but this method may change in the future to more precisely support case folding instead of caseDown()'s case mapping. Future code is encouraged to use caseDown(char) and caseUp(char) for case mapping, and this method only when case folding is preferred (such as for some case-insensitive comparisons). Case-insensitive comparisons are easier to do with caseUp(char) on both compared chars; that technique works for every alphabet except Georgian. This method will currently act exactly how Character.toLowerCase(char) acts on Java 25 on a PC.
      Parameters:
      c - any char; this should only return a case-folded different char for upper-case letters
      Returns:
      the single-char case-folded version of c, of it has one, otherwise c

    • caseDown

      public static char caseDown(char c)
      Returns the given char c's lower-case representation, if it has one, otherwise returns it verbatim. This is currently the same as caseFold(char), but this method may change in the future if the subtle distinction between case folding and case mapping is needed by this library. This is the counterpart to caseUp(char), but because of the complexities of... language, calling caseDown() and then caseUp() will not always return the original character. This has to do with how some characters, like lower-case s, have multiple upper-case conversions possible, and the same in the other direction. This method will act exactly how Character.toLowerCase(char) acts on Java 25 on a PC.
      Parameters:
      c - any char; this should only return a case-changed different char for upper-case letters
      Returns:
      the single-char lower-case version of c, of it has one, otherwise c

    • caseUp

      public static char caseUp(char c)
      The counterpart to caseDown(char) that returns the given char c's upper-case representation, if it has one, otherwise it returns it verbatim. This has dubiously correct behavior for digraphs and ligature chars, but they tend to be rare or even discouraged in practice. Case-insensitive comparisons are easier to do with caseUp() on both compared chars; this technique works for every alphabet except Georgian. This method will act exactly how Character.toUpperCase(char) acts on Java 25 on a PC.
      Parameters:
      c - any char; this should only return a case-changed different char for lower-case letters
      Returns:
      the single-char upper-case version of c, if it has one, otherwise c

    • matchBracket

      public static char matchBracket(char c)
      Finds the matching closing or opening bracket when given an opening or closing bracket as the char c. If c is not a bracket character this recognizes, then this will return c verbatim; you can check if the return value of this method is equal to c to determine if a matching bracket char is possible. This does recognize '<' as opening and '>' as closing, despite those two not being in Unicode's categories of opening or closing brackets, because more programmers should find that behavior useful and matching always should need to be specified anyway (you won't have '<' or '>' change meaning unless you're expecting a matching bracket).
      Parameters:
      c - any char; if it is a bracket this will different behavior than non-bracket characters
      Returns:
      a char; if c is a bracket this will return its opening or closing counterpart, otherwise returns c

    • reverseWithBrackets

      public static String reverseWithBrackets(CharSequence s)
      Returns a String that is the reverse of s, with any brackets also reversed via matchBracket(char).
      Parameters:
      s - a non-null CharSequence
      Returns:
      a String that is the reverse of s with any brackets also reversed

    • reverseEqual

      public static boolean reverseEqual(CharSequence left, CharSequence right)
      Returns true if left and right are reverses of each other with the same length.
      Parameters:
      left - a CharSequence
      right - another CharSequence
      Returns:
      true if left and right are reverses of each other

    • reverseBracketEqual

      public static boolean reverseBracketEqual(CharSequence left, CharSequence right)
      Returns true if left and right are reverses of each other with the same length, and any brackets also reversed via matchBracket(char).
      Parameters:
      left - a CharSequence
      right - another CharSequence
      Returns:
      true if left and right are reverses of each other, with brackets also reversed

    • decompress

      public CharBitSet decompress()
      When a Category's compression slows down its repeated usage, you can get an uncompressed data structure using this method.
      This allocates a new CharBitSet, which should be stored instead of generated more than once per Category.
      Returns:
      a new CharBitSet containing the same chars as this Category, uncompressed
